content.text:
# Grade I and II* listed buildings in Warrington

There are over 9,000 Grade I listed buildings and 20,000 Grade II* listed buildings in England. This page is a list of these buildings in the unitary authority of Warrington in Cheshire, including the town of Warrington and 18 other civil parishes.
Grade I
| grid_ref= SJ5687094711
| lat= 53.44759
| lon= -2.65018
| uid= 1075927
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The first railway viaduct to be built in the world, it was designed by George Stephenson for the Liverpool and Manchester Railway Company to carry the railway across the Sankey Valley.  It is constructed in brick faced with sandstone ashlar.  The viaduct is carried on nine semicircular arches.
| show_img = yes
| image=Sankey Viaduct - geograph.org.uk - 217761.jpg
| commonscat= Sankey Viaduct
| upload_desc= Sankey Viaduct over Sankey Brook (that Part in Warrington District)
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6394386300
| lat= 53.3723
| lon= -2.5434
| uid= 1139320
| show_notes=yes
| notes=There is some Norman fabric in the south wall of the nave, the south chapel was built as a chantry in about 1334, and the tower and most of the rest of the church date from 1525–39.  The clerestory was added in 1833, and the north vestry in 1851.  In 1873–74 Paley and Austin carried out a restoration.
| show_img = yes
| image=St Wilfrid's, Grappenhall.jpg
| upload_desc= Church of St Wilfred
|commonscat=St Wilfrid's church, Grappenhall
}}
Early to mid-17th century
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6833787244
| lat= 53.3811
| lon= -2.4776
| uid= 1227014
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This is a sandstone structure standing on an artificially stepped sandstone outcrop.  The shaft of the cross is contained in a square pavilion with square corner pillars, which has a roof with pedimented gables and a ball finial.
| show_img = yes
| image=Lymm Cross.jpg
| upload_desc= Lymm Cross
|commonscat=Lymm Cross
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6037592833
| lat= 53.4308
| lon= -2.5979
| uid= 1278428
| show_notes=yes
| notes=Additions and alterations have been made over the centuries, including the rebuilding of the chancel, sanctuary and vestry by A. W. N. Pugin in 1847–49, and the rebuilding of the spire and restoration of the church in 1869 by Paley and Austin.  The church is constructed in sandstone, and has a west tower.  Many of the furnishings were designed by Pugin.  Inside the church is the cross-arm of an Anglo-Saxon preaching cross dating from around 750.
| show_img = yes
| image=St Oswald's Church, Winwick.jpg
| upload_desc= Church of St Oswald
|commonscat=St Oswald's Church, Winwick
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6026088267
| lat= 53.3898
| lon= -2.5990
| uid= 1329748
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This was built as offices for Bank Hall, and were later used by the local authority.  The building has a three-bay rusticated and pedimented centre, and five brick bays on each side.
| show_img = yes
| image=Warrington Town Hall Eastern Outbuilding, Warrington.jpg
| upload_desc= Eastern Outbuilding to Town Hall
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6021888266
| lat= 53.3897
| lon= -2.5997
| uid= 1329725
| show_notes=yes
| notes=Designed by James Gibbs as a country house, named Bank House, for Thomas Patten, this in Palladian style.  It has three storeys and a hipped slate roof.  The house is constructed in red brick and rusticated stone.  In the centre is full-height portico with Composite columns carrying a pediment bearing the arms of the Patten family.  The entrance is in the middle storey and is approached by a double staircase.
| show_img = yes
| image=Warrington Town Hall.jpg
| upload_desc= Town Hall
|commonscat=Warrington Town Hall
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6017688259
| lat= 53.3897
| lon= -2.6003
| uid= 1261276
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This was built as stables for Bank Hall, and were later used as offices by the local authority.  The building has a three-bay rusticated and pedimented centre, and three brick bays on each side.
| show_img = yes
| image=Warrington Town Hall Western Outbuilding, Warrington.jpg
| upload_desc= Western Outbuilding to Town Hall
}}
|}
Grade II*
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6573783844
| lat= 53.3504
| lon= -2.5162
| uid= 1139363
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This originated as a threshing barn, cartshed and stable, which form an L-shaped plan.  It is timber-framed, with brick nogging, and stands on a sandstone plinth.  It is roofed with blue tiles.  The timber framing includes four crucks, two of which are complete, the other two are sawn off near the top.
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= Tanyard Farm Farmbuilding
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ5907089572
| lat= 53.4013
| lon= -2.6170
| uid= 1230619
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The hall underwent alterations during the 17th to the 19th centuries, and was restored and partly rebuilt in the 20th century, but only a fragment of the original hall has survived.  What does survive has an L-shaped plan, and is in three storeys.  It is constructed in brick with stone dressings and slate roofs, and has mullioned or mullioned and transomed windows.  The moated site on which the hall stands is a scheduled monument.
| show_img = yes
| image=Bewsey Old Hall.jpg
| commonscat= Bewsey Old Hall
| upload_desc= Bewsey Old Hall
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ5717293902
| lat= 53.44013
| lon= -2.64622
| uid= 1278505
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The gatehouse to the hall, now partly in ruins.  It is constructed in sandstone, forming an archway above the entrance to the drive.  The surviving features include the arch, which is four-centred with colonnettes (small columns), the springers of the fallen vault, and octagonal canted mock turrets supported by buttresses at the four corners.
| show_img = yes
| image=Bradlegh Hall Gatehouse.jpg
| commonscat= Gatehouse to Bradlegh Old Hall
| upload_desc= Gatehouse to Bradlegh Old Hall
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6797995162
| lat= 53.4522
| lon= -2.4837
| uid= 1159651
| show_notes=yes
| notes=A farmhouse that has been altered and extended.  It is constructed in rendered brick with a slate roof.  It is in two storeys with an attic, and has four bays, including an added wing.  The windows are mullioned. Inside the house is another mullioned window, moulded beams, and a priest hole.
| show_img = yes
| image=Hallcroft Hall Farm (geograph 4028525).jpg
| commonscat= Holcroft Hall
| upload_desc= Holcroft Hall
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6685496903
| lat= 53.4678
| lon= -2.5008
| uid= 1139388
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This is part of what was originally on old hall, later converted into a barn.  It is basically timber framed with brick cladding and a stone slate roof.  It is in two bays, with an extra half-bay at each end.  The timber roof is open, of unusual construction for the region, and said to be "spectacular".
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= North Barn at Hurst Hall
}}
Late 16th century
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6843987041
| lat= 53.3792
| lon= -2.4759
| uid= 1265849
| show_notes=yes
| notes=Constructed in sandstone and brick, it was originally an E-shaped Elizabethan moated house.  Since then, the hall has been altered and restored, particularly in the 19th century.
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= Lymm Hall
}}
| grid_ref= SJ5984685254
| lat= 53.3626
| lon= -2.6049
| uid= 1139352
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The church was designed by Paley and Austin, and paid for by Sir Gilbert Greenall.  It is in Decorated style, and constructed in sandstone with Westmorland green slate roofs.  The church has a cruciform plan, with a large central tower decorated with chequerwork and surmounted by an octagonal spire.
| show_img = yes
| image=St John's Church, Warrington.jpg
| commonscat= St John the Evangelist's Church, Higher Walton
| upload_desc= Church of St John the Evangelist
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6199592973
| lat= 53.4321
| lon= -2.5734
| uid= 1231049
| show_notes=yes
| notes=A brick country house standing on a sandstone plinth with sandstone dressings.  It is in two storeys and consists of a hall with two cross wings, and another right wing.  The windows are mullioned and/or transomed. Some of the 19th-century additions have been demolished.
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= Myddleton Hall
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6054889042
| lat= 53.3967
| lon= -2.5948
| uid= 1161591
| show_notes=yes
| notes=Designed by John Douglas in High Victorian Gothic style.  It is constructed in red brick with dressings in blue brick.  The church has a tower and an apsidal chancel.  It is now redundant, and was converted into an indoor climbing centre in 1996.
| show_img = yes
| image=St Ann's Church, Warrington.jpg
| commonscat= Old St Ann's Church, Warrington
| upload_desc= Church of St Ann
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6153288397
| lat= 53.3910
| lon= -2.5799
| uid= 1329734
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The earliest fabric in the church dates from the 14th century.  Following damage in the Civil War, the tower was rebuilt in 1696 and the nave in 1770.  The south aisle was added in the early 19th century.  Most of the fabric of the present church results from an extensive restoration between 1859 and 1867 by Frederick and Horace Francis, during which the spire was added.  The spire is  high, and one of the highest in England.  The north transept forms the regimental chapel of the South Lancashire Regiment.
| show_img = yes
| image=St Elphin's Church, Warrington.jpg
| upload_desc= Church of St Elphin
|commonscat=St Elphin's Church, Warrington
}}
| grid_ref= SJ5918687795
| lat= 53.3854
| lon= -2.6151
| uid= 1329757
| show_notes=yes
| notes=A sandstone church with tiled roofs designed by Bodley and Garner, it is now redundant.  It consists of a nave, north aisle, chancel and south porch.  There is a bellcote on the east end of the nave.  The church is unusual in that it has a central nave arcade and another arcade between the nave and the aisle.
| show_img = yes
| image=Former St Luke's CofE Church, Liverpool Road - geograph.org.uk - 852645.jpg
| commonscat= St Luke's Church, Warrington
| upload_desc= Church of St Luke
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6059788168
| lat= 53.3894
| lon= -2.5917
| uid= 1161522
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This is a Georgian church designed in the style of James Gibbs.  Its front is in sandstone, the back in brick with stone dressings.  A clock tower was added to the west of the church in 1862.  Further alterations were made during the 20th century.  Features include a Doric doorcase, with Ionic pilasters above, a cornice and a plain parapet.  In the east wall is a Venetian window.
| show_img = yes
| image=Holy Trinity Church, Warrington - geograph.org.uk - 108610.jpg
| commonscat= Holy Trinity Church, Warrington
| upload_desc= Church of the Holy Trinity
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6130488348
| lat= 53.3905
| lon= -2.5833
| uid= 1310102
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This probably originated as a single house, later divided into three cottages.  It is timber-framed with painted brick infill on a stone plinth.  There are two storeys, the upper storey being jettied.  The windows are casements with wooden mullions.  At the rear are single-storey extensions, and three half-dormers.
| show_img = yes
| image=Cromwell's Cottage - geograph.org.uk - 522801.jpg
| commonscat= Cromwell House, Warrington
| upload_desc= Cromwell House
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6022688157
| lat= 53.38876
| lon= -2.59949
| uid= 1261277
| show_notes=yes
| notes=A set of ornate gates in cast iron, partly gilded, designed by Kershaw and Crook, and made at the Coalbrookdale Company at Ironbridge. They were shown at the International Exhibition in London in 1862, and erected here in 1895.  Statues depicting Nike by John Bell stand on the four posts.  Among the decorations are the Prince of Wales's feathers and his motto.
| show_img = yes
| image=Warrington town hall.jpg
| upload_desc= Entrance Gates, Piers and Lamps
|commonscat=Warrington Town Hall gates
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6018488207
| lat= 53.38923
| lon= -2.60011
| uid= 1239919
| show_notes=yes
| notes=There are lamps part-way down the east and west drives leading to the Town Hall that was designed by James Gibbs.
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= Lamps on East and West Drives of Town Hall
}}
| grid_ref= SJ5968187619
| lat= 53.38383
| lon= -2.60757
| uid= 1139433
| show_notes=yes
| notes=The transporter bridge was built to carry materials across the River Mersey between two parts of the Crosfield's factory.  It is a steel structure with a span of  between the towers.  The bridge was designed by William Henry Hunter and built by William Arrol.  The structure is also a scheduled monument.
| show_img = yes
| image=Wartranny.jpg
| commonscat= Warrington Transporter Bridge
| upload_desc= Transporter Bridge to Part of Joseph Crosfield and Sons Ltd's Works
}}
| grid_ref= SJ6055388303
| lat= 53.3899
| lon= -2.5946
| uid= 1139399
| show_notes=yes
| notes=A timber-framed public house that has been much altered.  The front facing Market Place is in elaborate black-and-white work, including quatrefoils, standing on a red sandstone plinth.  It is in three storeys, including two jettied gables, and two continuous rows of small-pane windows.  Inside the public house is a mixture of original 17th-century and later panelling.
| show_img = yes
| image=The Barley Mow pub, Warrington - DSC05951.JPG
| commonscat= Barley Mow, Warrington
| upload_desc= Ye Olde Barley Mow Public House (excluding the Side Facade)
}}
| show_listed = yes
| date_listed=
| grid_ref= SJ6056088293
| lat= 53.3900
| lon= -2.5945
| uid= 1310100
| show_notes=yes
| notes=This façade dates from a 19th-century refronting of the public house that originated in the 16th century.  It is in brick, with two storeys and an attic.  There is a round-arched entrance flanked by wooden pilasters, and a tympanum that incorporates the carving of a barley sheaf.  The windows are sashes, and there are two small blocked windows in the attic.
| show_img = yes
| image=
| upload_desc= Ye Olde Barley Mow Public House (only the Side Facade)
}}
Notes
